content: Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein’s future in question

tag: html body div section section div div div div a span

content: Former Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein.

tag: html body div section section div div figure span cite span
html body div section section div div div p strong span
html body div section section div div div p em span
content: A previous version of this article said Rosenstein was out, citing reports from other news outlets. The article is now being updated as news develops.

tag: html body div section section div div div p span
content: It looks like Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein will stay in his post until at least Thursday, when he’s set to meet with

tag: html body div section section div div div p a span
html body div section section div div div p span
html body div section section div div div p span
content: Monday was a wild day in Washington, as different news reports gave rise to speculation that Rosenstein had resigned or even been fired. It started when

tag: html body div section section div div div p a span
html body div section section div div div p span
content: reported on Monday morning that Rosenstein offered to resign in a conversation with White House Chief of Staff John Kelly. Others, like the

tag: html body div section section div div div p a span
html body div section section div div div p span
html body div section section div div div p a span
html body div section section div div div p span
html body div section section div div div p span
content: But then conflicting reports surfaced, with

tag: html body div section section div div div p a span
html body div section section div div div p span
content: and others saying Rosenstein expected to be fired during a Monday meeting at the White House. That led to widespread confusion about what, exactly, Rosenstein’s fate would be.

tag: html body div section section div div div p span
content: Later in the day, it became clear that Rosenstein was at the White House for a scheduled meeting and had spoken with the president on the phone. They agreed to meet in three days when Trump comes back from a high-stakes diplomatic gathering at the UN.

tag: html body div section section div div div p span
content: The conflicting news comes three days after the

tag: html body div section section div div div p a span
html body div section section div div div p span
content: reported that the deputy attorney general said he wanted to record conversations with Trump last year and discussed using the 25th Amendment to remove the president from office. Rosenstein denied the report, and one source told the Times that Rosenstein had merely been joking.

tag: html body div section section div div div p span
content: But if Rosenstein were on the way out, it would be highly significant news.

tag: html body div section section div div div p span
content: Rosenstein is the man responsible for overseeing Mueller’s investigation into possible collusion between the Trump campaign and the Russian government during the 2016 US presidential election. That’s because Attorney General Jeff Sessions, Rosenstein’s boss,

tag: html body div section section div div div p a span
html body div section section div div div p span
content: himself from the probe after it became clear he’d provided false and misleading

tag: html body div section section div div div p a span
html body div section section div div div p span
content: to Congress about his own contacts with Russia.

tag: html body div section section div div div p span
content: Rosenstein has therefore spent more than a year

tag: html body div section section div div div p span
html body div section section div div div p span
content: On one hand, he’s committed to

tag: html body div section section div div div p a span
html body div section section div div div p span
html body div section section div div div p a span
html body div section section div div div p span
content: inside and outside Congress who believed it’s biased against the president and had urged Trump to fire the special counsel. But Rosenstein couldn’t champion the investigation too much or he’d draw Trump’s ire.

tag: html body div section section div div div p span
content: Rosenstein’s possible departure would strike at the heart of the Trump-Russia investigation because Mueller has to run major investigative decisions past the deputy attorney general.

tag: html body div section section div div div p a span
html body div section section div div div p span
content: , who would replace Rosenstein if he left, could simply refuse to approve Mueller’s requests. That would slow the whole investigation to a crawl — or lead to Mueller’s ouster if he felt there was a reason to do so.

tag: html body div section section div div div p a span
html body div section section div div div p span
content: had refused to do that. He instead allowed Mueller’s probe to proceed unimpeded, while Mueller indicted top members of Trump’s campaign, including former campaign chair

tag: html body div section section div div div p a span
html body div section section div div div p span
content: , on tax, financial, and bank fraud charges.

tag: html body div section section div div div p a span
html body div section section div div div p span
content: later pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy against the US and one count of conspiracy to obstruct justice and is now cooperating with the Mueller investigation.

tag: html body div section section div div div p span
content: The future of the Mueller probe, and possibly even Trump’s presidency, depends on how well Rosenstein performed his delicate balancing act.

tag: html body div section section div div div h3 span
content: Rosenstein has to keep Trump and the Justice Department happy. That’s not easy.

tag: html body div section section div div div p span
content: Rosenstein’s performance during a congressional hearing last December showed how he has had to navigate the difficult situation he’s in.

tag: html body div section section div div div p span
content: Here’s what happened: On the night of December 12, mere hours before Rosenstein would testify at a House Judiciary Committee hearing, the Justice Department showed reporters some anti-Trump

tag: html body div section section div div div p a span
html body div section section div div div p span
content: . The messages were from two FBI officials, Peter Strzok and Lisa Page, who had corresponded throughout the 2016 presidential election.

tag: html body div section section div div div p span
content: Strzok, a former top FBI counterintelligence official who was on Mueller’s investigative team,

tag: html body div section section div div div p a span
html body div section section div div div p span
content: Page that Trump was an “idiot.” He also wanted Clinton to defeat Trump in the election — in another message, he

tag: html body div section section div div div p a span
html body div section section div div div p span
html body div section section div div div p span
content: There was also a text that seemingly implied Strzok and Page were working on an “insurance policy” in case Trump won the election. But the Wall Street Journal

tag: html body div section section div div div p a span
html body div section section div div div p span
content: on December 18 that Strzok’s text was really about the need to investigate possible Trump-Russia ties. Mueller removed Strzok from his staff last July, and the Strzok-Page exchanges remain subject to an internal investigation by the Justice Department. Still, some

tag: html body div section section div div div p a span
content: conservatives in and out of government

tag: html body div section section div div div p span
content: think these texts show that the Mueller probe was working against the president.

tag: html body div section section div div div p span
content: It’s unclear if Rosenstein authorized the release of the texts, but some legal analysts thought the DOJ made the messages public the night before Rosenstein’s big hearing to curry favor with the anti-Mueller crowd on the House Judiciary Committee.

tag: html body div section section div div div p span
content: "It's appalling behavior by the department," Matthew Miller, a spokesperson for the Justice Department in the Obama administration,

tag: html body div section section div div div p a span
html body div section section div div div p span
content: Business Insider about the release of the texts at the time. "This is an ongoing investigation in which these employees have due-process rights, and the political leadership at DOJ has thrown them to the wolves so Rosenstein can get credit from House Republicans at his hearing."

tag: html body div section section div div div p span
content: Rosenstein defended the release of the texts during the hearing, saying, "We consulted with the inspector general to determine that he had no objection to releasing the material,” in response to a question about the texts by Rep. Jamie Raskin (D-MD). “If he had, we would not have released it,” Rosenstein said.

tag: html body div section section div div div p span
html body div section section div div div p em span
html body div section section div div div p span
content: defended Mueller in that same session. Rep. Jerrold Nadler (D-NY), the committee’s ranking member,

tag: html body div section section div div div p a span
html body div section section div div div p span
content: Rosenstein the most highly anticipated question of the session: “If you were ordered today to fire Mr. Mueller, what would you do?”

tag: html body div section section div div div p span
content: “If there were good cause, I would act. If there were no good cause, I would not,” Rosenstein

tag: html body div section section div div div p a span
html body div section section div div div p span
content: . He then went on to defend Mueller personally, saying, “It would've been difficult to find anyone more qualified for this job.”

tag: html body div section section div div div p span
content: These exchanges show that Rosenstein was trying to stand up for the probe while still appeasing Trump and his allies. Benjamin Wittes, an expert on national security law at the Brookings Institution, wrote on the Lawfare blog that Rosenstein may pay a price for doing both.

tag: html body div section section div div div p span
content: “Rosenstein here has, at a minimum, contributed to [the political] circus — at the expense of his own employees,” he

tag: html body div section section div div div p a span
html body div section section div div div p span
content: after the hearing. “The DOJ and FBI workforces will not forget that. Nor should they.”

tag: html body div section section div div div p span
content: Those 24 hours encapsulated Rosenstein’s political two-step. One minute he defended the release of texts that served as ammunition for Mueller critics and Trump allies to lambast the investigation; the next, he shielded Mueller from criticism by those

tag: html body div section section div div div p em span
html body div section section div div div p span
content: anti-Mueller conservatives and Trump allies — and put his own job at risk.

tag: html body div section section div div div p span
content: Keeping both sides happy allowed Rosenstein to say he supported his staff while also backing Trump. The deputy attorney general played a deft game, and those who had previously worked with him felt he could pull it off.

tag: html body div section section div div div p span
content: “What you have in Rod is somebody that is battle-tested,” Julie Myers Wood, a prosecutor and former colleague of Rosenstein’s, told me in an interview last December, months before Rosenstein’s ouster. “I can’t think of anyone that is more prepared to handle this situation than him.”

tag: html body div section section div div div p span
html body div section section div div div p a span
html body div section section div div div p span
content: told a crowd that “the Department of Justice is not going to be extorted.” He continued: “We’re going to do what’s required by the rule of law, and any kind of threats that anybody makes are not going to affect the way we do our job.”

tag: html body div section section div div div h3 span
content: Rosenstein is in the middle of a major political controversy

tag: html body div section section div div div p span
content: Rosenstein has long been considered an apolitical straight shooter by those who worked with him. “He has a directness about him — there’s no bullshit,” Philip Heymann, Rosenstein’s former professor at Harvard Law School and later his colleague, told me before Trump reportedly let Rosenstein go. “He says what he thinks, but he’s always fair.”

tag: html body div section section div div div p span
content: President George W. Bush appointed Rosenstein as the US attorney for Maryland in 2005. President Barack Obama kept him on, making Rosenstein only

tag: html body div section section div div div p a span
html body div section section div div div p span
content: — out of a total of 93 — retained by the new administration. Rosenstein officially joined the Trump administration last April as deputy attorney general after receiving broad

tag: html body div section section div div div p a span
html body div section section div div div p span
html body div section section div div div p span
content: But Rosenstein finds himself in the middle of a major political controversy just two weeks into his new job. On May 9, 2017, he co-authored a

tag: html body div section section div div div p a span
html body div section section div div div p span
content: with Sessions making the case that Trump should fire then-FBI Director James Comey because of how Comey had handled the results of the agency’s Clinton investigation.

tag: html body div section section div div div p span
html body div section section div div div p a span
html body div section section div div div p span
content: , “the FBI’s reputation and credibility have suffered substantial damage, and it has affected the entire Department of Justice.”

tag: html body div section section div div div p span
html body div section section div div div p a span
html body div section section div div div p span
content: : “I cannot defend the director’s handling of the conclusion of the investigation of Secretary Clinton’s emails, and I do not understand his refusal to accept the nearly universal judgment that he was mistaken.”

tag: html body div section section div div div p span
content: Trump fired Comey later that day,

tag: html body div section section div div div p a span
html body div section section div div div p span
content: the Sessions-Rosenstein letter as his reason. Pro-Trump Republicans and conservative media

tag: html body div section section div div div p a span
html body div section section div div div p span
content: the decision to remove Comey, but Democrats were furious. And some of that fury extended to Rosenstein.

tag: html body div section section div div div p span
html body div section section div div div p a span
html body div section section div div div p span
content: shortly after the Comey firing that he had “lost any confidence I might have had” in Rosenstein, whose “first official action was putting his name on that letter, basically making what appeared to be bogus reasons [for] firing the FBI director.”

tag: html body div section section div div div p span
content: Those who know Rosenstein say he recommended firing Comey not because he wanted to please Trump, but rather because he believed Comey hurt the FBI’s reputation. “He’s guided by justice, not by politics,” Steve Levin, a former colleague of Rosenstein’s in Maryland, told me in an interview before the firing.

tag: html body div section section div div div p span
html body div section section div div div p a span
html body div section section div div div p span
content: Mueller as the special counsel, authorizing him to look into possible Trump-Russia ties as well as “any matters that arose or may arise from the investigation.”

tag: html body div section section div div div p span
content: It seems quite clear that Rosenstein isn’t in Trump’s pocket. But Trump himself wondered aloud where Rosenstein’s true loyalties lay,

tag: html body div section section div div div p a span
html body div section section div div div p span
content: on June 16, “I am being investigated for firing the FBI Director by the man who told me to fire the FBI Director! Witch Hunt.”

tag: html body div section section div div div h3 span
content: The Trump-Russia probe could be in serious trouble

tag: html body div section section div div div p span
html body div section section div div div p a span
html body div section section div div div p span
content: from pursuing the investigation the way he saw fit, and he made every indication that he intended to continue letting Mueller proceed with his investigation.

tag: html body div section section div div div p span
content: But if Rosenstein is fired or resigns, Francisco could change all that, especially if Trump applies significant pressure. That said, if Francisco

tag: html body div section section div div div p em span
html body div section section div div div p span
content: fire Mueller, the investigation might not be completely undermined,

tag: html body div section section div div div p span
html body div section section div div div p a span
html body div section section div div div p span
content: have pleaded guilty and prosecutors are likely to continue to

tag: html body div section section div div div p a span
html body div section section div div div p span
content: from the beginning of the investigation in June 2016.

tag: html body div section section div div div p span
content: And the future is still very unclear. If Francisco doesn’t do Trump’s bidding, the president could simply fire him. That’s possibly more detrimental to the Mueller probe.

tag: html body div section section div div div p span
content: Asha Rangappa, a legal expert at Yale's Jackson Institute for Global Affairs,

tag: html body div section section div div div p a span
html body div section section div div div p span
content: in a post for the Just Security blog last December that a new deputy attorney general could effectively cripple the Mueller investigation by rejecting Mueller’s requests to investigate more people, obtain new evidence, or pursue charges against additional people, for instance.

tag: html body div section section div div div p span
content: In effect, Rosenstein’s possible ouster now has put the Mueller probe in its most precarious position to date — possibly allowing Trump to escape further investigation into him, his associates, and his family.
